trans-unit.source: Azure AD Xamarin Getting Started | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure AD Xamarin Getting Started | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: How to build a Xamarin application that integrates with Azure AD for sign in and calls Azure AD protected APIs using OAuth.
trans-unit.target: How to build a Xamarin application that integrates with Azure AD for sign in and calls Azure AD protected APIs using OAuth.

trans-unit.source: Xamarin allows you to write applications in C# that can run on several different platforms, including mobile devices and pc's alike.
trans-unit.target: Xamarin allows you to write applications in C# that can run on several different platforms, including mobile devices and pc's alike.

trans-unit.source: If you're building an app using Xamarin, Azure AD makes it simple and straightforward for you to authenticate your users with their Active Directory accounts.
trans-unit.target: If you're building an app using Xamarin, Azure AD makes it simple and straightforward for you to authenticate your users with their Active Directory accounts.

trans-unit.source: It also enables your application to securely consume any web API protected by Azure AD, such as the Office 365 APIs or the Azure API.
trans-unit.target: It also enables your application to securely consume any web API protected by Azure AD, such as the Office 365 APIs or the Azure API.

trans-unit.source: For Xamarin apps that need to access protected resources, Azure AD provides the Active Directory Authentication Library, or ADAL.
trans-unit.target: For Xamarin apps that need to access protected resources, Azure AD provides the Active Directory Authentication Library, or ADAL.

trans-unit.source: ADAL’s sole purpose in life is to make it easy for your app to get access tokens.
trans-unit.target: ADAL’s sole purpose in life is to make it easy for your app to get access tokens.

trans-unit.source: To demonstrate just how easy it is, here we’ll build a "Directory Searcher" app that:
trans-unit.target: To demonstrate just how easy it is, here we’ll build a "Directory Searcher" app that:

trans-unit.source: Runs on iOS, Android, Windows Desktop, Windows Phone, and Windows Store.
trans-unit.target: Runs on iOS, Android, Windows Desktop, Windows Phone, and Windows Store.

trans-unit.source: Uses a single portable class library (PCL) to authenticate users and get tokens for the Azure AD Graph API
trans-unit.target: Uses a single portable class library (PCL) to authenticate users and get tokens for the Azure AD Graph API

trans-unit.source: Searches a directory for users with a given UPN.
trans-unit.target: Searches a directory for users with a given UPN.

trans-unit.source: To build the complete working application, you’ll need to:
trans-unit.target: To build the complete working application, you’ll need to:

trans-unit.source: Set up your Xamarin development environment
trans-unit.target: Set up your Xamarin development environment

trans-unit.source: Register your application with Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: Register your application with Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: Install & Configure ADAL.
trans-unit.target: Install & Configure ADAL.

trans-unit.source: Use ADAL to get tokens from Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: Use ADAL to get tokens from Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: To get started, <linkText>download a skeleton project</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>download the completed sample</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To get started, <linkText>download a skeleton project</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>download the completed sample</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Each is a Visual Studio 2013 solution.
trans-unit.target: Each is a Visual Studio 2013 solution.

trans-unit.source: You'll also need an Azure AD tenant in which you can create users and register an application.
trans-unit.target: You'll also need an Azure AD tenant in which you can create users and register an application.

trans-unit.source: If you don't already have a tenant, <linkText>learn how to get one</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you don't already have a tenant, <linkText>learn how to get one</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: There are several different ways you might want to set up Xamarin, depending on the specific platforms you wish to target.
trans-unit.target: There are several different ways you might want to set up Xamarin, depending on the specific platforms you wish to target.

trans-unit.source: Since this tutorial includes projects for iOS, Android, and Windows, we'll elect to use Visual Studio 2013 and the <linkText>Xamarin.iOS Build Host</linkText><title></title>, which will require:
trans-unit.target: Since this tutorial includes projects for iOS, Android, and Windows, we'll elect to use Visual Studio 2013 and the <linkText>Xamarin.iOS Build Host</linkText><title></title>, which will require:

trans-unit.source: A windows machine to run Visual Studio & the Windows apps
trans-unit.target: A windows machine to run Visual Studio & the Windows apps

trans-unit.source: An OSX machine (if you want to be able to run the iOS app)
trans-unit.target: An OSX machine (if you want to be able to run the iOS app)

trans-unit.source: A Xamarin Business subscription (a [free trial](http://developer.xamarin.com/guides/cross-platform/gettingstarted/beginningaxamarintrial/) is sufficient)
trans-unit.target: A Xamarin Business subscription (a [free trial](http://developer.xamarin.com/guides/cross-platform/gettingstarted/beginningaxamarintrial/) is sufficient)

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Xamarin for Windows</linkText><title></title>, which includes Xamarin.iOS, Xamarin.Android, and the Visual Studio Integration (recommended for this sample).
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Xamarin for Windows</linkText><title></title>, which includes Xamarin.iOS, Xamarin.Android, and the Visual Studio Integration (recommended for this sample).

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Xamarin for OS X</linkText><title></title>, which includes Xamarin.iOS (and the Xamarin.iOS Build Host), Xamarin.Android, Xamarin.Mac, and Xamarin Studio.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Xamarin for OS X</linkText><title></title>, which includes Xamarin.iOS (and the Xamarin.iOS Build Host), Xamarin.Android, Xamarin.Mac, and Xamarin Studio.

trans-unit.source: We recommend you begin with the <linkText>Xamarin Download Page</linkText><title></title>, installing Xamarin on both your Mac and PC.
trans-unit.target: We recommend you begin with the <linkText>Xamarin Download Page</linkText><title></title>, installing Xamarin on both your Mac and PC.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have both machines available, you can still run the sample, but certain projects will have to be omitted.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have both machines available, you can still run the sample, but certain projects will have to be omitted.

trans-unit.source: Follow the [detailed installation guides](http://developer.xamarin.com/guides/cross-platform/gettingstarted/installation/) for iOS and Android, and if you would like to understand more about the options available to you for development, have a look at the [Building Cross Platform Applications](http://developer.xamarin.com/guides/cross-platform/applicationfundamentals/buildingcrossplatformapplications/part1-understandingthexamarinmobileplatform/) guide.
trans-unit.target: Follow the [detailed installation guides](http://developer.xamarin.com/guides/cross-platform/gettingstarted/installation/) for iOS and Android, and if you would like to understand more about the options available to you for development, have a look at the [Building Cross Platform Applications](http://developer.xamarin.com/guides/cross-platform/applicationfundamentals/buildingcrossplatformapplications/part1-understandingthexamarinmobileplatform/) guide.

trans-unit.source: You do not need to setup a device for development at this time, nor do you need a Apple Developer Program subscription (unless, of course, you want to run the iOS app on a device).
trans-unit.target: You do not need to setup a device for development at this time, nor do you need a Apple Developer Program subscription (unless, of course, you want to run the iOS app on a device).

trans-unit.source: Once you've completed the necessary setup, open the solution in Visual Studio to get started.
trans-unit.target: Once you've completed the necessary setup, open the solution in Visual Studio to get started.

trans-unit.source: You will find six projects: five platform-specific projects and one portable class library that will be shared across all platforms, DirectorySearcher.cs
trans-unit.target: You will find six projects: five platform-specific projects and one portable class library that will be shared across all platforms, DirectorySearcher.cs

trans-unit.source: To enable your app to get tokens, you’ll first need to register it in your Azure AD tenant and grant it permission to access the Azure AD Graph API:
trans-unit.target: To enable your app to get tokens, you’ll first need to register it in your Azure AD tenant and grant it permission to access the Azure AD Graph API:

trans-unit.source: Sign into the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: Sign into the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: In the left hand nav, click on Active Directory
trans-unit.target: In the left hand nav, click on Active Directory

trans-unit.source: Select a tenant in which to register the application.
trans-unit.target: Select a tenant in which to register the application.

trans-unit.source: Click the Applications tab, and click Add in the bottom drawer.
trans-unit.target: Click the Applications tab, and click Add in the bottom drawer.

trans-unit.source: Follow the prompts and create a new Native Client Application.
trans-unit.target: Follow the prompts and create a new Native Client Application.

trans-unit.source: The Name of the application will describe your application to end-users
trans-unit.target: The Name of the application will describe your application to end-users

trans-unit.source: The Redirect Uri is a scheme and string combination that Azure AD will use to return token responses.
trans-unit.target: The Redirect Uri is a scheme and string combination that Azure AD will use to return token responses.

trans-unit.source: Enter a value, e.g. http://DirectorySearcher.
trans-unit.target: Enter a value, e.g. http://DirectorySearcher.

trans-unit.source: Once you’ve completed registration, AAD will assign your app a unique client identifier.
trans-unit.target: Once you’ve completed registration, AAD will assign your app a unique client identifier.

trans-unit.source: You’ll need this value in the next sections, so copy it from the Configure tab.
trans-unit.target: You’ll need this value in the next sections, so copy it from the Configure tab.

trans-unit.source: Also in Configure tab, locate the "Permissions to Other Applications" section.
trans-unit.target: Also in Configure tab, locate the "Permissions to Other Applications" section.

trans-unit.source: For the "Azure Active Directory" application, add the Access Your Organization's Directory permission under Delegated Permissions.
trans-unit.target: For the "Azure Active Directory" application, add the Access Your Organization's Directory permission under Delegated Permissions.

trans-unit.source: This will enable your application to query the Graph API for users.
trans-unit.target: This will enable your application to query the Graph API for users.

trans-unit.source: Now that you have an application in Azure AD, you can install ADAL and write your identity-related code.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have an application in Azure AD, you can install ADAL and write your identity-related code.

trans-unit.source: In order for ADAL to be able to communicate with Azure AD, you need to provide it with some information about your app registration.
trans-unit.target: In order for ADAL to be able to communicate with Azure AD, you need to provide it with some information about your app registration.

trans-unit.source: Begin by adding ADAL to each of the projects in the solution using the Package Manager Console.
trans-unit.target: Begin by adding ADAL to each of the projects in the solution using the Package Manager Console.

trans-unit.source: PM> Install-Package Microsoft.IdentityModel.Clients.ActiveDirectory -ProjectName DirectorySearcherLib -IncludePrerelease
trans-unit.target: PM> Install-Package Microsoft.IdentityModel.Clients.ActiveDirectory -ProjectName DirectorySearcherLib -IncludePrerelease

trans-unit.source: PM> Install-Package Microsoft.IdentityModel.Clients.ActiveDirectory -ProjectName DirSearchClient-Android -IncludePrerelease
trans-unit.target: PM> Install-Package Microsoft.IdentityModel.Clients.ActiveDirectory -ProjectName DirSearchClient-Android -IncludePrerelease

trans-unit.source: PM> Install-Package Microsoft.IdentityModel.Clients.ActiveDirectory -ProjectName DirSearchClient-Desktop -IncludePrerelease
trans-unit.target: PM> Install-Package Microsoft.IdentityModel.Clients.ActiveDirectory -ProjectName DirSearchClient-Desktop -IncludePrerelease

trans-unit.source: PM> Install-Package Microsoft.IdentityModel.Clients.ActiveDirectory -ProjectName DirSearchClient-iOS -IncludePrerelease
trans-unit.target: PM> Install-Package Microsoft.IdentityModel.Clients.ActiveDirectory -ProjectName DirSearchClient-iOS -IncludePrerelease

trans-unit.source: PM> Install-Package Microsoft.IdentityModel.Clients.ActiveDirectory -ProjectName DirSearchClient-Universal.Windows -IncludePrerelease
trans-unit.target: PM> Install-Package Microsoft.IdentityModel.Clients.ActiveDirectory -ProjectName DirSearchClient-Universal.Windows -IncludePrerelease

trans-unit.source: PM> Install-Package Microsoft.IdentityModel.Clients.ActiveDirectory -ProjectName DirSearchClient-Universal.WindowsPhone -IncludePrerelease
trans-unit.target: PM> Install-Package Microsoft.IdentityModel.Clients.ActiveDirectory -ProjectName DirSearchClient-Universal.WindowsPhone -IncludePrerelease

trans-unit.source: You should notice that two library references are added to each project - the PCL portion of ADAL and a platform-specific portion.
trans-unit.target: You should notice that two library references are added to each project - the PCL portion of ADAL and a platform-specific portion.

trans-unit.source: In the DirectorySearcherLib project, open DirectorySearcher.cs.
trans-unit.target: In the DirectorySearcherLib project, open DirectorySearcher.cs.

trans-unit.source: Change the class member values to reflect the values you input into the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: Change the class member values to reflect the values you input into the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: Your code will reference these values whenever it uses ADAL.
trans-unit.target: Your code will reference these values whenever it uses ADAL.

trans-unit.source: The tenant is the domain of your Azure AD tenant, e.g. contoso.onmicrosoft.com
trans-unit.target: The tenant is the domain of your Azure AD tenant, e.g. contoso.onmicrosoft.com

trans-unit.source: The clientId is the clientId of your application you copied from the portal.
trans-unit.target: The clientId is the clientId of your application you copied from the portal.

trans-unit.source: The returnUri is the redirectUri you entered in the portal, e.g. http://DirectorySearcher.
trans-unit.target: The returnUri is the redirectUri you entered in the portal, e.g. http://DirectorySearcher.

trans-unit.source: Almost all of the app's authentication logic lies in DirectorySearcher.SearchByAlias(...).
trans-unit.target: Almost all of the app's authentication logic lies in DirectorySearcher.SearchByAlias(...).

trans-unit.source: All that is necessary in the platform-specific projects is to pass a contextual parameter to the DirectorySearcher PCL.
trans-unit.target: All that is necessary in the platform-specific projects is to pass a contextual parameter to the DirectorySearcher PCL.

trans-unit.source: First, open DirectorySearcher.cs and add a new parameter to the SearchByAlias(...) method.
trans-unit.target: First, open DirectorySearcher.cs and add a new parameter to the SearchByAlias(...) method.

trans-unit.source: IPlatformParameters is the contextual parameter that encapsulates the platform-specific objects that ADAL needs to perform authentication.
trans-unit.target: IPlatformParameters is the contextual parameter that encapsulates the platform-specific objects that ADAL needs to perform authentication.

trans-unit.source: Next, initialize the AuthenticationContext - ADAL’s primary class.
trans-unit.target: Next, initialize the AuthenticationContext - ADAL’s primary class.

trans-unit.source: This is where you pass ADAL the coordinates it needs to communicate with Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: This is where you pass ADAL the coordinates it needs to communicate with Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: Then call AcquireTokenAsync(...), which accepts the IPlatformParameters object and will invoke the authentication flow necessary to return a token to the app.
trans-unit.target: Then call AcquireTokenAsync(...), which accepts the IPlatformParameters object and will invoke the authentication flow necessary to return a token to the app.

trans-unit.source: AcquireTokenAsync(...) will first attempt to return a token for the requested resource (the Graph API in this case) without prompting the user to enter their credentials (via caching or refreshing old tokens).
trans-unit.target: AcquireTokenAsync(...) will first attempt to return a token for the requested resource (the Graph API in this case) without prompting the user to enter their credentials (via caching or refreshing old tokens).

trans-unit.source: Only if necessary, it will show the user the Azure AD sign in page before acquiring the requested token.
trans-unit.target: Only if necessary, it will show the user the Azure AD sign in page before acquiring the requested token.

trans-unit.source: You can then attach the access token to the Graph API request in the Authorization header:
trans-unit.target: You can then attach the access token to the Graph API request in the Authorization header:

trans-unit.source: That's all for the DirectorySearcher PCL and your app's identity-related code.
trans-unit.target: That's all for the DirectorySearcher PCL and your app's identity-related code.

trans-unit.source: All that remains is to call the SearchByAlias(...) method in each platform's views, and where necessary add code for correctly handling the UI lifecycle.
trans-unit.target: All that remains is to call the SearchByAlias(...) method in each platform's views, and where necessary add code for correctly handling the UI lifecycle.

trans-unit.source: In MainActivity.cs, add a call to SearchByAlias(...) in the button click handler:
trans-unit.target: In MainActivity.cs, add a call to SearchByAlias(...) in the button click handler:

trans-unit.source: You also need to override the OnActivityResult lifecycle method to forward any authentication redirects back to the appropriate method.
trans-unit.target: You also need to override the OnActivityResult lifecycle method to forward any authentication redirects back to the appropriate method.

trans-unit.source: ADAL provides a helper method for this in Android:
trans-unit.target: ADAL provides a helper method for this in Android:

trans-unit.source: In MainWindow.xaml.cs, simply make a call to SearchByAlias(...) passing a WindowInteropHelper in the desktop's PlatformParameters object:
trans-unit.target: In MainWindow.xaml.cs, simply make a call to SearchByAlias(...) passing a WindowInteropHelper in the desktop's PlatformParameters object:

trans-unit.source: In DirSearchClient_iOSViewController.cs, the iOS PlatformParameters object simply takes a reference to the View Controller:
trans-unit.target: In DirSearchClient_iOSViewController.cs, the iOS PlatformParameters object simply takes a reference to the View Controller:

trans-unit.source: In Windows Store, open MainPage.xaml.cs and implement the Search method, which uses a helper method in a shared project to update UI as necessary.
trans-unit.target: In Windows Store, open MainPage.xaml.cs and implement the Search method, which uses a helper method in a shared project to update UI as necessary.

trans-unit.source: In Windows Phone, open MainPage.xaml.cs and implement the Search method, which uses the same helper method in a shared project to update UI.
trans-unit.target: In Windows Phone, open MainPage.xaml.cs and implement the Search method, which uses the same helper method in a shared project to update UI.

trans-unit.source: Congratulations!
trans-unit.target: Congratulations!

trans-unit.source: You now have a working Xamarin app that has the ability to authenticate users and securely call Web APIs using OAuth 2.0 across five different platforms.
trans-unit.target: You now have a working Xamarin app that has the ability to authenticate users and securely call Web APIs using OAuth 2.0 across five different platforms.

trans-unit.source: If you haven’t already, now is the time to populate your tenant with some users.
trans-unit.target: If you haven’t already, now is the time to populate your tenant with some users.

trans-unit.source: Run your DirectorySearcher app, and sign in with one of those users.
trans-unit.target: Run your DirectorySearcher app, and sign in with one of those users.

trans-unit.source: Search for other users based on their UPN.
trans-unit.target: Search for other users based on their UPN.

trans-unit.source: ADAL makes it easy to incorporate common identity features into your application.
trans-unit.target: ADAL makes it easy to incorporate common identity features into your application.

trans-unit.source: It takes care of all the dirty work for you - cache management, OAuth protocol support, presenting the user with a login UI, refreshing expired tokens, and more.
trans-unit.target: It takes care of all the dirty work for you - cache management, OAuth protocol support, presenting the user with a login UI, refreshing expired tokens, and more.

trans-unit.source: All you really need to know is a single API call, authContext.AcquireToken*(…).
trans-unit.target: All you really need to know is a single API call, authContext.AcquireToken*(…).

trans-unit.source: For reference, the completed sample (without your configuration values) is provided <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For reference, the completed sample (without your configuration values) is provided <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can now move on to additional identity scenarios.
trans-unit.target: You can now move on to additional identity scenarios.

trans-unit.source: You may want to try:
trans-unit.target: You may want to try:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Secure a .NET Web API with Azure AD >></linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Secure a .NET Web API with Azure AD >></linkText><title></title>
